0.question:
A candy factory uses raw materials A, B, and C to produce three different brands of candy: Brand X, Brand Y, and Brand Z. The content proportions of A, B, and C in each brand, the costs of the raw materials, the monthly usage limits for each raw material, as well as the unit processing cost and selling price of each candy brand are shown in Table 1-17.The question is: How many kilograms of each brand of candy should the factory produce each month in order to maximize its profit?Please formulate a linear programming mathematical model for this problem.
\begin{table}[h]
    \centering
    \caption{Raw Materials and Candy Production Data}
    \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.2}
    \begin{tabular}{c|ccc|c|c}
        \toprule
        Raw Materials & X & Y & Z & Raw Material Cost(dollar/kg) & Monthly Usage Limit(kg) \\
        \midrule
        A & $\geq 60\%$ & $\geq 30\%$ & & 2.00 & 2000 \\
        B & & & & 1.50 & 2500 \\
        C & $\leq 20\%$ & $\leq 50\%$ & $\leq 60\%$ & 1.00 & 1200 \\
        \midrule
        Processing Cost(dollar/kg) & 0.50 & 0.40 & 0.30 & & \\
        Selling Price(dollar/kg) & 3.40 & 2.85 & 2.25 & & \\
        \bottomrule
    \end{tabular}
\end{table}

1.question:
A livestock farm raises animals for sale. It is required that each animal must receive at least 700g of protein, 30g of minerals, and 100mg of vitamins per day. There are five types of feed available for selection. The nutritional content per kilogram and the unit price of each type of feed are shown in Table 1-22.

\begin{table}[h]
    \centering
    \caption{Nutritional Content and Price of Feed}
    \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.2}
    \begin{tabular}{c|c|c|c|c}
        \toprule
        Feed & Protein (g) & Minerals (g) & Vitamins (mg) & Price (dollar/kg) \\
        \midrule
        1 & 3 & 1.0 & 0.5 & 0.2 \\
        2 & 2 & 0.5 & 1.0 & 0.7 \\
        3 & 1 & 0.2 & 0.2 & 0.4 \\
        4 & 6 & 2.0 & 2.0 & 0.3 \\
        5 & 18 & 0.5 & 0.8 & 0.8 \\
        \bottomrule
    \end{tabular}
\end{table}

The goal is to determine a feed selection plan that both meets the nutritional requirements for animal growth and minimizes the cost.

2.question:
Hongyin Company has committed to providing the following loan amounts at the beginning of each year for a construction project over a period of four years starting from 2003:
\begin{itemize}
    \item Year 2003 — 100 thousand dollars
    \item Year 2004 — 150 thousand dollars
    \item Year 2005 — 120 thousand dollars
    \item Year 2006 — 110 thousand dollars
\end{itemize}

 All the above loan funds must be raised before the end of 2002. However, in order to make full use of the funds, any surplus (after meeting the annual loan amounts) can be invested in the following projects:

\begin{enumerate}
    \item At the beginning of 2003, purchase Bond A, with a term of 3 years. Upon maturity, the total return (principal and interest) will be 140\% of the investment. The purchase is limited to 60 thousand dollars. 
    \item At the beginning of 2003, purchase Bond B, with a term of 2 years. Upon maturity, the total return (principal and interest) will be 125\% of the investment. The purchase is limited to 90 thousand dollars. 
    \item At the beginning of 2004, purchase Bond C, with a term of 2 years. Upon maturity, the total return (principal and interest) will be 130% of the investment. The purchase is limited to 50 thousand dollars. 
    \item At the beginning of each year, any amount of surplus funds may be deposited in a bank account at an annual interest rate of 4%, with withdrawal at the end of the same year. 
\end{enumerate}

 Question:How should Hongyin Company utilize the raised funds to ensure that the total amount needed to be raised at the end of 2002 is minimized?

3.question:
At the beginning of the year, Hongdou Garment Factory launched a new fashion product. Based on experience and market research, the predicted demand for this product over the next six months is as follows: 
 January:3,000 units, February:3,600 units, March:4,000 units, April: 4,600 units, May:4,800 units, June:5,000 units 
 Each unit requires 4 hours of skilled labor and 150 dollars worth of raw materials to produce. The selling price is 240 dollars per unit. 
 At the beginning of January, the factory has 80 skilled workers, each working 160 hours per month. To meet production needs, the factory can recruit and train new workers. Training a new worker takes 50 hours of a skilled worker’s time for instruction, and the training period lasts one month, after which the trainee can become a skilled worker. Skilled workers are paid 2,000 dollars per month. Trainees receive a living allowance of 800 dollars during the training month. After completing training, new workers receive the same salary and work efficiency as skilled workers. Each month, 2\% of skilled workers (including those newly trained and on the job for at least one month) leave due to various reasons. 
 The factory starts the year with 400 units of inventory and requires that the ending inventory in June not exceed 100 units. Additionally, if garments are not delivered in the month of production, they incur a storage cost of 10 dollars per unit per month. Design a labor and production plan for the factory that satisfies the monthly and end-of-June inventory requirements, while maximizing the total revenue from January to June.

4.question:
A cargo ship has three compartments: front, middle, and rear. Their volumes and maximum allowable loads are shown in \ref{table1-24}. 
 There are three types of cargo to be shipped, with data shown in  \ref{table1-25}.

\begin{table}[h]
    \centering
    \caption{Maximum Allowable Load and Volume}
    \label{table1-24}
    \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
        \hline
        \textbf{Item} & \textbf{Front Compartment} & \textbf{Middle Compartment} & \textbf{Rear Compartment} \\
        \hline
        Max Allowable Load (t) & 2000 & 3000 & 1500 \\
        \hline
        Volume ($m^3$) & 4000 & 5000 & 1500 \\
        \hline
    \end{tabular}
\end{table}

\begin{table}[h]
    \centering
    \caption{Cargo Data}
    \label{table1-25}
    \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
        \hline
        \textbf{Cargo Type} & \textbf{Quantity (pieces)} & \textbf{Volume per Piece ($m^3$/piece)} & \textbf{Weight per Piece (t/piece)} & \textbf{Freight Rate (dollar/piece)} \\
        \hline
        A & 600 & 10 & 8 & 1000 \\
        \hline
        B & 1000 & 5 & 6 & 700 \\
        \hline
        C & 800 & 7 & 4 & 600 \\
        \hline
    \end{tabular}
\end{table}

 For maritime safety, the actual load weight in the front, middle, and rear compartments must maintain roughly the same proportion as their respective maximum allowable loads. 
 Specifically: The load weight ratios between the front/middle and rear/middle compartments must not deviate by more than 15\% from the ratios of their respective max allowable loads. The ratio between front and rear compartments must not deviate by more than 10\%. 
 Question: How many pieces of cargo A, B, and C should be loaded in total to maximize revenue, while meeting the volume, weight, and balance constraints? 
 Please formulate the linear programming model for this problem.

5.question:
A factory produces three types of products: I, II, and III, all of which go through two processing stages, A and B. Stage A can be performed on either machine A\textsubscript{1} or A\textsubscript{2}.Stage B can be carried out on any of machines B\textsubscript{1}, B\textsubscript{2}, or B\textsubscript{3}. Processing capabilities: Product I can be processed on any of the A and B machines. Product II can be processed on any A machine, but only B\textsubscript{1} can be used for stage B. Product III can only be processed on A\textsubscript{2} for stage A and B\textsubscript{2} for stage B. The processing time per unit, available machine hours, machine processing cost, raw material cost, and selling price are listed in Table 1-18. Task: Develop an optimal production plan to maximize the factory’s profit, taking into account machine capacity constraints, processing routes, costs, and selling prices.

& \textbf{I} & \textbf{II} & \textbf{III} & & \\

A\textsubscript{1} & 5 & 10 &  & 6 000 & 0.05 \\
\hline
A\textsubscript{2} & 7 & 9 & 12 & 10 000 & 0.03 \\
\hline
B\textsubscript{1} & 6 & 8 &  & 4 000 & 0.06 \\

\hline

9.question:
A city has three flour mills, which supply flour to three food processing factories. The output of each flour mill, the processing capacity of each food factory, and the unit transportation cost between each flour mill and food factory are shown in Table 3-31. It is assumed that the profit per unit of flour processed into food is: Factory 1: 12 yuan, Factory 2: 16 yuan, Factory 3: 11 yuan, All flour mills and food factories are managed by the same administrative body. Objective: Determine a flour allocation plan that maximizes total benefit, considering both transportation costs and unit profits.

12.question:
A company has decided to use 1000 thousand yuan of a new product development fund to invest in the development of three new products: A, B, and C. Forecasted return on investment (ROI) for each product is: Product A: 5%, Product B: 7%, Product C: 10%, Due to associated risks, the company has defined the following priority constraints: 1.At least 300 thousand yuan must be invested in Product A. 2.To diversify investment risk, no single product may receive more than 35% of the total fund. 3.At least 10% of the fund (i.e., 1 million yuan) must be reserved for emergency use.4.The objective is to maximize total profit from the investment. 
Please formulate a model to maximize the total investment profit(in thousand yuan).

15.question:
Factories $A_1$ and $A_2$ produce a certain type of material. Due to high demand and insufficient supply, a new factory needs to be built. There are two construction options: $A_3$ and $A_4$. The material is needed in four locations: $B_1, B_2, B_3, B_4$. The annual production capacities of each factory, the annual demand at each location, and the unit transportation cost of materials from each factory to each demand location $c_{ij}$ (in thousand yuan per kiloton, where i,j = 1,2,3,4) are shown in Table 5-2. 

\begin{table}[h]
    \centering
    \caption{Table 5-2: Unit Transportation Costs from Factories to Demand Locations}
    \renewcommand{\arraystretch}{1.2}
    \begin{tabular}{c|cccc|c}
        \toprule
        $c_{ij}$ (thousand yuan/kt) & $B_1$ & $B_2$ & $B_3$ & $B_4$ & Production Capacity (kt/year) \\
        \midrule
        $A_1$ & 2 & 9 & 3 & 4 & 400 \\
        $A_2$ & 8 & 3 & 5 & 7 & 600 \\
        $A_3$ & 7 & 6 & 1 & 2 & 200 \\
        $A_4$ & 4 & 5 & 2 & 5 & 200 \\
        \midrule
        Demand (kt/year) & 350 & 400 & 300 & 150 & \\
        \bottomrule
    \end{tabular}
\end{table}

If factory $A_3$ is built, its annual production cost is estimated to be 1200 thousand yuan;if $A_4$ is built, the annual production cost is 1500 thousand yuan.The goal is to decide whether to build factory $A_3$ or $A_4$ in order to minimize the total annual cost, which includes all transportation costs and the production cost(in thousand yuan) of the new factory.

17.question:
A commercial company plans to open 5 new stores and has decided to assign the construction of these stores to 5 construction companies. The construction cost quotations (in thousand yuan) from construction company $A_i$ (for i = 1, 2, \cdots, 5) to build store $B_j$ (for j = 1, 2, \cdots, 5) are shown in Table 5-10.To minimize the total construction cost(in thousand yuan), how should the company assign the construction tasks among the 5 construction companies?

19.question: \noindent\textbf{5.12 Truck Delivery Problem (Set Covering Problem)} Longyun Company must currently deliver goods to 5 customers: 1 unit of goods to Customer A, 2 units to Customer B, 3 units to Customer C, 4 units to Customer D, 8 units to Customer E. The company has 4 trucks, each used only once: Truck 1: capacity of 2 units, Truck 2: capacity of 6 units, Truck 3: capacity of 8 units, Truck 4: capacity of 11 units. The cost of using truck j is c_j. Constraints: A truck cannot deliver to both Customer A and Customer C. A truck cannot deliver to both Customer B and Customer D. Objective:Formulate an integer programming model to determine how to assign the deliveries to the trucks to minimize the total transportation cost.

27.question:
A hospital operates 24 hours a day, and the number of nurses needed in each time period is as follows: $2\!:\!00\!\sim\!6\!:\!00\!\longrightarrow\!10$ nurses, $6\!:\!00\!\sim$ 10:00\!\longrightarrow\!15$ nurses, $10:00\!\sim\!14:00\!\longrightarrow\!25$ nurses, $14:00\!\sim\!18\!:\!00\!\longrightarrow\!20$ nurses, $18\,;00\!\sim\!22\!:\!00\!\longrightarrow\!18$ nurses,$22\!:\!00\!\sim\!2\!:\!00\!-\!\!\!-\!12$ nurses. Nurses are scheduled in 6 shifts, starting at: $2:00\,,6:00\,,10:00\,,14:00\,,18:00\,,22:00$ and each nurse works 8 consecutive hours.

Task:Determine the minimum number of nurses the hospital needs to schedule in total in order to meet the staffing requirements.

28.question:
A hospital operates 24 hours a day. The number of nurses required during each 4-hour shift is:$2\!:\!00\!\sim\!6\!:\!00\!\longrightarrow\!10$ nurses, $6\!:\!00\!\sim$ 10:00\!\longrightarrow\!15$ nurses, $10:00\!\sim\!14:00\!\longrightarrow\!25$ nurses, $14:00\!\sim\!18\!:\!00\!\longrightarrow\!20$ nurses, $18\,;00\!\sim\!22\!:\!00\!\longrightarrow\!18$ nurses, $22\!:\!00\!\sim\!2\!:\!00\!-\!\!\!-\!12$ nurses. Nurses work in 6 shifts, each starting at: $2:00\,,6:00\,,10:00\,,14:00\,,18:00\,,22:00$ and each nurse works 8 consecutive hours. 

Now there’s a new scenario: The hospital can hire both full-time and temporary (contract) nurses. Both types work the same 8-hour shifts. Wages: Full-time nurse = ¥10/hour. Contract nurse = ¥15/hour. Task:Should the hospital hire contract nurses? If so, how many should be hired in each shift to minimize total labor cost, while still satisfying the required nurse coverage?

The company currently has a warehouse with a capacity of 5,000 dan, and as of January 1, it has: 1,000 dan of grain in stock, 20,000 yuan in available capital, Estimated purchase and sale prices for the first quarter are shown below: Table 1-8 – Grain Prices
MonthPurchase Price (yuan/dan)Selling Price (yuan/dan)
12.853.10
23.053.25
32.902.95
Grain arrives in the month it is purchased, but can only be sold starting in the next month.Cash payment upon delivery. The target inventory at the end of March is 2,000 dan.

30.question:
1.33 A farm has 100 hectares (hm²) of land and 15,000 yuan of funds available for production development. The farm has 3,500 person-days of labor in autumn and winter, and 4,000 person-days in spring and summer. If the labor is not fully used, workers can go out to work; the wage income in spring and summer is 2.1 yuan/person-day, and in autumn and winter is 1.8 yuan/person-day.The farm grows three types of crops: soybeans, corn, and wheat, and raises dairy cows and chickens.When planting crops, no special investment is needed. When raising animals:Each dairy cow requires an investment of 400 yuan,Each chicken requires an investment of 3 yuan. Each dairy cow also requires 1.5 hm² of land for forage planting, and labor: 100 person-days in autumn and winter, 50 person-days in spring and summer, Annual net income is 400 yuan per cow.Chickens do not occupy land, but require labor:0.6 person-days per chicken in autumn and winter,0.3 person-days per chicken in spring and summer,Annual net income is 2 yuan per chicken.The current chicken house allows a maximum of 3,000 chickens to be raised, and the cowshed allows a maximum of 32 dairy cows.The labor required and income from the three crops are shown in Table 1-9. Table 1-9
ItemSoybeansCornWheat
Autumn and Winter labor (person-days)203510
Spring and Summer labor (person-days)507540
Annual net income (yuan/hm²)175300120
Try to determine the farm’s operational plan that will maximize annual net income.

31.question: 1.34 The market demand for products I and II is as follows: Product I requires 10,000 units per month from January to April, 30,000 units per month from May to September, and 100,000 units per month from October to December. Product II requires 15,000 units per month from March to September, and 50,000 units per month in other months.The production costs of the factory for the two products are: For product I: 5 yuan per unit if produced from January to May; 4.50 yuan per unit if produced from June to December. For product II: 8 yuan per unit if produced from January to May; 7 yuan per unit if produced from June to December. The total monthly production capacity of the factory for both products must not exceed 120,000 units. The volume per unit is 0.2 m³ for product I and 0.4 m³ for product II, and the factory’s warehouse volume capacity is 15,000 m³. Requirements:(a) Show that the above problem has no feasible solution.(b) If the factory’s warehouse is insufficient, storage space can be rented from an external factory. If using the in-house warehouse, the cost per m³ per month is 1 yuan; if renting from an external warehouse, the cost increases to 1.5 yuan per m³ per month. Under the condition of meeting market demand, determine how the factory should schedule production to minimize the total cost of production and inventory storage.

32.question:
1.35 The contract order quantities for a factory’s products I, II, and III in each quarter of the coming year are shown in Table 1-10. Table 1-10
ProductQuarter
1234
I1 5001 00020001 200
Ⅱ1 5001 5001 2001 500
Ⅲ1 0002 00015002500
At the beginning of Q1, there is no inventory of the three products. By the end of Q4, there must be an inventory of 150 units for each product. The factory has 15,000 working hours available per quarter. Producing one unit of products I, II, and III requires 2, 4, and 3 hours, respectively. Due to a change in production equipment, product I cannot be produced in Q2. If a product is not delivered on time, late delivery penalties are: 20 yuan per unit per quarter for products I and II, 10 yuan per unit per quarter for product III, If a product is produced but not delivered within the same quarter, the inventory cost is 5 yuan per unit per quarter. Question: How should the factory schedule its production to minimize the total cost of late delivery penalties and inventory holding costs?

Month1234
Required warehouse area (m²)1 5001 0002 0001 200
When the contract rental period is longer, the warehouse rental fee per square meter enjoys greater discounts. The specific data is shown in Table 1-15. Table 1-15
Contract rental duration (months)1234

Therefore, the factory may, depending on its needs, sign one or multiple contracts at the beginning of each month, with different rental areas and durations. The objective is to determine how to sign rental contracts such that the total rental cost is minimized.

34.question:
A fleet of strategic bombers is ordered to destroy an enemy military target. It is known that the target has four key parts, and destroying any one of them is sufficient to achieve the objective. To carry out this mission, the constraints are: fuel consumption is limited to 48,000 liters, 48 heavy bombs, and 32 light bombs. When carrying a heavy bomb, each liter of fuel allows the aircraft to fly 2 km; when carrying a light bomb, each liter allows it to fly 3 km. In addition, for each bombing sortie, besides fuel consumption for the round trip (note: when flying empty, each liter of fuel allows flight of 4 km), 100 liters of fuel are consumed each for takeoff and landing. The relevant data is shown in Table 1-17. Table 1-17
Key PartDistance from Airbase (km)Probability of Destruction
per Heavy Bombper Light Bomb
14500.100.08
24800.200.16
35400.150.12
46000.250.20
To maximize the probability of destroying the enemy military target, how should the bombing plan be determined?

35.question:
1.42 A timber storage and transportation company has a large warehouse used for storing and selling timber. Due to seasonal price fluctuations of timber, the company purchases timber at the beginning of each quarter. A portion is sold during the current quarter, and another portion is stored for sale in later quarters. It is known that the company’s warehouse has a maximum timber storage capacity of 20 thousand m³, and the storage cost is (a + b u) yuan per m³, where a = 70, b = 100, and u is the storage time in quarters. The purchase prices, selling prices, and estimated maximum sales volumes per quarter are given in Table 1-18. Table 1-18
QuarterPurchase Price (thousand yuan per thousand m³)Selling Price (thousand yuan per thousand m³)Estimated Max Sales Volume (thousand m³)
Winter410425100
Spring430440140
Summer460465200
Autumn450455160
Because timber is not suitable for long-term storage, all stored timber must be sold by the end of autumn each year. Task: Formulate a linear programming model for this problem in order to maximize the company’s annual profit(in thousand yuan).

36.question: 1.45 A company has three tasks that require the recruitment of skilled workers (technicians) and unskilled workers (laborers) to complete. Task 1 can be completed either by one technician alone, or by a team consisting of one technician and two laborers. Task 2 can be completed by either one technician or one laborer alone.Task 3 can be completed either by a team of five laborers, or by a team consisting of one technician leading three laborers. It is known that: The weekly wage is 100 yuan for each technician, and 80 yuan for each laborer. Each person works 48 hours per week, but their effective working time per week is: Technician: 42 hours, Laborer: 36 hours, To complete the three tasks, the total effective working time required per week is: Task 1: 10,000 hours, Task 2: 20,000 hours, Task 3: 30,000 hours. The number of workers that can be recruited is no more than 400 technicians and 800 laborers. Problem: Formulate a mathematical model to determine how many technicians and laborers should be recruited, so that the total wage cost is minimized.

38.question: 2.42 A certain cultural and educational supplies factory uses raw material white base paper to produce three types of products: manuscript paper, diaries, and exercise books. The factory currently has 100 workers, and the monthly supply of white base paper is $30000~kg$ .It is known that the workers’ labor productivity is: each person per month can produce 30 bundles of manuscript paper, or 30 dozens of diaries, or 30 boxes of exercise books. It is known that the raw material consumption is: each bundle of manuscript paper uses  $3~{\frac{1}{3}}~\mathrm{kg}$  of white base paper, each dozen of diaries uses $13~{\frac{1}{3}}~\mathbf{kg}$  of white base paper, each box of exercise books uses $26~{\frac{2}{3}}~\mathbf{kg}$  of white base paper. It is also known that the profit for producing one bundle of manuscript paper is 2 yuan, one dozen of diaries is 3 yuan, and one box of exercise books is 1 yuan. Question: Determine, under the current production conditions, the production plan that yields the maximum profit.

39.question: 2.42 A certain cultural and educational supplies factory uses raw material white base paper to produce three types of products: manuscript paper, diaries, and exercise books. The factory currently has 100 workers, and the monthly supply of white base paper is 30,000 kg. It is known that a worker’s labor productivity is: each person per month can produce 30 bundles of manuscript paper, or 30 dozens of diaries, or 30 boxes of exercise books. It is known that the raw material consumption is: each bundle of manuscript paper uses $3~{\frac{1}{3}}~\mathrm{kg}$ of white base paper, each dozen of diaries uses $13~{\frac{1}{3}}~\mathbf{kg}$ of white base paper, each box of exercise books uses $26~{\frac{2}{3}}~\mathbf{kg}$  of white base paper. It is also known that the profit for producing: one bundle of manuscript paper is 2 yuan, one dozen of diaries is 3 yuan,one box of exercise books is 1 yuan. Question: If the supply of white base paper remains unchanged, and when the number of workers is insufficient, temporary workers can be hired at a wage cost of 40 yuan per person per month, then:Should the factory hire temporary workers? And if so, how many is optimal?

YearShips under normal productionShips under overtime productionCost per ship (normal) (thousand yuan)

It is known that under overtime production, the cost per ship is 70 thousand yuan higher than under normal production. Additionally, if a ship is produced but not delivered in the same year, each year of delay results in an additional maintenance and storage loss of 40 thousand yuan per ship. At the time of contract signing, the shipyard already has two undelivered ships in stock. The shipyard also wishes to have one spare ship in storage at the end of the third year after fulfilling the contract deliveries. Question: How should the shipyard arrange its production plan to meet the above requirements while minimizing total cost(in thousand yuan)?

47.question: To ensure flight safety, the engines on the aircraft must be compulsorily replaced and overhauled every six months. A maintenance plant estimates that, starting from the next half-year, the engine replacement demand for a certain type of fighter aircraft over the next three years (i.e., each half-year) will be: 100, 70, 80, 120, 150, 140. When replacing an engine, it can either be replaced with a new one, or with a repaired used engine. It is known that the purchase cost of each new engine is 10 thousand yuan, while repairing used engines has two options: Fast repair: 2 thousand yuan per engine, delivered in half a year (i.e., sent in the current period, ready in the next period); Slow repair: 10,000 yuan per engine, but takes one year for delivery (i.e., sent in the current period, ready in the period after next). The plant has just received this engine replacement and repair task. It is also known that this type of fighter aircraft will be decommissioned after three years, and the engines will be scrapped after that.Question:In order to meet the maintenance demand over the next three years (six half-year periods), how many engines should be newly purchased, and how many should be sent for fast repair and slow repair in each period, so that the total maintenance cost(in thousand yuan) is minimized?

55.question: 5.25 A master’s student majoring in Operations Research at a university is required to choose from the following seven courses: Calculus, Operations Research, Data Structures, Managerial Statistics, Computer Simulation, Computer Programming, and Forecasting. Among these, the student must select two Mathematics courses, two Operations Research courses, and two Computer Science courses. Some courses belong to only one category: Calculus is a Mathematics course, and Computer Programming is a Computer Science course. However, some courses span multiple categories: Operations Research counts as both Operations Research and Mathematics; Data Structures belong to both Computer Science and Mathematics; Managerial Statistics belong to both Mathematics and Operations Research; Computer Simulation belongs to both Computer Science and Operations Research; Forecasting belongs to both Operations Research and Mathematics. If a course falls into two categories, selecting it counts as one course in each of those two categories.In addition, some courses have prerequisites: to take Computer Simulation or Data Structures, one must first take Computer Programming; to take Managerial Statistics, one must first take Calculus; and to take Forecasting, one must first take Managerial Statistics.Question: What is the minimum number of courses a master’s student must take, and which courses must be taken, in order to meet the above requirements?

60.question: A company goes to a university to recruit one graduating student majoring in management. From many applicants, three candidates are shortlisted for interviews, to be interviewed one by one. The interview rules are as follows: When interviewing the first or second candidate: If satisfied (scored 3 points), and the decision is to hire, the interviews end immediately. If not satisfied (scored 1 point), the candidate is rejected and the interview continues with the next person. If somewhat satisfied (scored 2 points), there are two choices: either hire the candidate and stop the interviews, or reject and continue the interviews. However, once a candidate is rejected, they cannot be recalled later even after seeing other candidates. If both the first and second candidates are rejected, then the third candidate must be hired regardless of their score. Based on past experience: The probability of a candidate being satisfactory is 20%, Somewhat satisfactory is 50%, Unsatisfactory is 30%. Goal: Determine a hiring strategy that maximizes the expected score of the hired candidate.

The specific shift times are as follows: Shift 1: 2:00–10:00, Shift 2: 6:00–14:00, Shift 3: 10:00–18:00, Shift 4: 14:00–22:00,Shift 5: 18:00–2:00 (next day), Each nurse works 5 shifts per week, scheduled on different days. A head nurse is in charge of creating the duty schedule. The scheduling plan must be personnel- or cost-efficient, while also being reasonable and practical. The following is a plan under consideration: Plan 1: Each nurse works 5 consecutive days, followed by 2 days off, and works a different shift each day, cycling through Shift 1 to Shift 5 in sequence. For example:,If a nurse starts on Monday, she works:Shift 1 on Monday,Shift 2 on Tuesday,…,Shift 5 on Friday; Another nurse starting on Wednesday would work: Shift 1 on Wednesday,…,Shift 5 on Sunday. Question: How can we minimize the total number of nurses required under Plan 1?

  \multirow{5}{*}{\RaggedRight Equipment} & Grinding & 0.5 & 0.7 & -- & -- & 0.3 & 0.2 & 0.5 \\

  & Horizontal Drill & 0.2 & -- & 0.8 & -- & -- & -- & 0.6 \\
  & Boring Machine & 0.05 & 0.03 & -- & 0.07 & 0.1 & -- & 0.08 \\
  & Planer & -- & -- & 0.01 & -- & 0.05 & -- & 0.05 \\
  \midrule
  \multicolumn{2}{c}{Profit (yuan)} & 100 & 60 & 80 & 40 & 110 & 90 & 30 \\
  \bottomrule
  \end{tabular}
  \end{table}

  From January to June, maintenance is scheduled for some machines, during which they cannot be used for production: January: 1 grinding machine, February: 2 horizontal drills, March: 1 boring machine, April: 1 upright drill, May: 1 grinding machine and 1 upright drill, June: 1 planer and 1 horizontal drill. The maximum market demand for each product from January to June is shown in Table C-4.  

  Table C-4  

  \begin{table}[h]
  \centering
  \caption{Combined Table}
  \begin{tabular}{ccccccccc}
  \toprule
  Month & I & II & III & IV & V & VI & VII \\
  \midrule
  Jan & 500 & 1000 & 300 & 300 & 800 & 200 & 100 \\
  Feb & 600 & 500 & 200 & 0 & 400 & 300 & 150 \\
  Mar & 300 & 600 & 0 & 0 & 500 & 400 & 100 \\
  Apr & 200 & 300 & 400 & 500 & 200 & 0 & 100 \\
  May & 0 & 100 & 500 & 100 & 1000 & 300 & 0 \\
  Jun & 500 & 500 & 100 & 300 & 1100 & 500 & 60 \\
  \bottomrule
  \end{tabular}
  \end{table}
  Additional constraints: Unsold units can be stored, with a monthly storage cost of 5 yuan per unit; Storage limit: No more than 100 units per product at any time; Initial inventory (January 1st): 0 for all products; Final inventory requirement (end of June): 50 units of each product. The factory works 24 days per month, 2 shifts per day, 8 hours per shift. Assume that processing order across machines is not considered. Task: How should the factory plan production and inventory over the 6 months to maximize total profit?

80.question:
A subsidiary of Tiantian Food Company produces two types of pastries, Product I and Product II, using raw materials A and B. The amount of raw material (in kg) consumed per thousand boxes of each product, the monthly supply of materials, the unit price of materials, and the wholesale price of the two products (in thousand yuan per thousand boxes) are shown in Table C-5.  

  Table C-5  

  \begin{table}[h]
  \centering
  \caption{Table C-5}
  \begin{tabular}{cccccc}
  \toprule
  \multicolumn{2}{c}{\textbf{Product}} & \multirow{2}{*}{\textbf{I}} & \multirow{2}{*}{\textbf{II}} & \textbf{Monthly Supply (t)} & \textbf{Price (thousand yuan/t)} \\
  \cmidrule(lr){1-2} \cmidrule(lr){5-6}
  \textbf{Raw Material} & & & & & \\
  \midrule
  A & & 1 & 2 & 6 & 9.9 \\
  B & & 2 & 1 & 8 & 6.6 \\
  \midrule
  \multicolumn{2}{c}{\textbf{Wholesale Price}} & 30 & 20 & & \\
  \bottomrule
  \end{tabular}
  \end{table}

  According to market estimates: The monthly sales of Product II do not exceed 2 thousand boxes. The sales volume of Product II does not exceed that of Product I by more than 1 thousand boxes. Task: Calculate the maximum possible wholesale revenue under the given constraints.

81.question:
A factory plans to relocate some of its production workshops from the urban area to satellite towns. The benefit of doing so lies in lower land, rent, and pollution treatment costs. However, this move will increase transportation costs between workshops. The factory currently has five workshops: A, B, C, D, and E. Two satellite towns are under consideration: Town α and Town β. It is required that no more than 3 workshops be located in any one area — whether the urban area, Town α, or Town β. The annual cost savings from relocating workshops from the urban area to the satellite towns are shown in Table C-18. Table C-18 (10,000 yuan/year)
WorkshopABCDE
To α10015010020050
To β100200150150150
However, relocation causes an increase in transportation costs, which depends on: C_{ik}: Annual transport volume (in tons/year) between workshops i and k. D_{jl}: Transportation cost per ton from location j to location l. These are provided in Table C-19 and Table C-20, respectively. \begin{table}[h] \centering \caption{Table C-19 $C_{ik}$ (Table C-19 $C_{ik}$ value) (t/year)} \begin{tabular}{ccccc} \toprule & B & C & D & E \\ \midrule A & 0 & 1000 & 1500 & 0 \\ B & & 1400 & 1200 & 0 \\ C & & & 0 & 2000 \\ D & & & & 700 \\ \bottomrule \end{tabular} \end{table} \begin{table}[h] \centering \caption{(Table C-20 $D_{jl}$ value) (yuan/t)} \begin{tabular}{cccc} \toprule & α & β & Urban \\ \midrule α & 500 & 1400 & 1300 \\ β & & 500 & 900 \\ Urban & & & 1000 \\ \bottomrule \end{tabular} \end{table} Determine a relocation plan for the workshops that minimizes the total cost
